Situation1: Their partner is going through a serious personal crisis and relies on them for consistent emotional reassurance and presence.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: I stood in the crowded polling station, my phone buzzing in my pocket with another message from Mark. He was having a rough day—his father’s health had taken a turn, and he needed me, just as he had all week. I wanted to be there, to answer right away, to reassure him that he wasn’t alone. But I was also here to vote, and the official’s voice cut through my thoughts, calling for everyone with last names A–M to move to the new line. My last name put me squarely in that group. The new line was longer, slower, but the instructions were clear. I glanced at the original line, moving quickly, and felt the weight of the official’s expectant gaze. I knew I was supposed to follow the rules, to do my civic duty properly. But Mark’s messages kept coming, each one more desperate, and I felt torn—between being the wife he needed and the responsible voter I was expected to be. My heart pounded as I stood frozen, caught between the pull of two worlds, unsure which demand to answer first.
